celestial.name: Sun
celestial.basic: Also called "Sol", it is at the centre of our solar system and is responsible for the Earth’s climate and weather.
celestial.mass: Accounts for some 99.86 % of the total mass of the Solar System
celestial.diameter: 1392684 km where one million Earths could fit inside the Sun
celestial.distance: from earth is approx 149.6 million km. It takes about 8 minutes and 19 seconds for light to reach us.

celestial.name: Mercury
celestial.basic: The smallest planet in the Solar System is the closest planet to the Sun and due to its proximity it is not easily seen except during twilight. A year on Mercury is just 88 days long.

celestial.name: Venus
celestial.basic: Also known as the Morning Star and the Evening Star is named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty. It has similar size and mass as Earth and is therefore regarded as the Earth’s sister planet. Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most other planets.

celestial.name: Earth
celestial.basic: The only known planet to support life is the largest of the terrestrial planets. It is the only planet in our solar system not to be named after a Greek or Roman deity.

celestial.name: Mars
celestial.basic: Named after the Roman god of war is home to the tallest mountain in the solar system.

celestial.name: Jupiter
celestial.basic: It is two and a half times more massive than all the other planets in the solar system combined. It is made primarily of gases and is therefore known as a “gas giant”. It has the shortest day of all the planets.

celestial.name: Saturn
celestial.basic: It has 150 moons and smaller moonlets.

celestial.name: Uranus
celestial.basic: The first planet discovered with the use of a telescope.

celestial.name: Neptune
celestial.basic: Named after the Roman god of the sea. Its position was determined using mathematical predictions.
